important_phrase: Recent rains improved soil conditions in some areas of the District, while parts of Georgia, Alabama, Louisiana, and Florida experienced dry conditions
Business contacts indicated that from late November through December overall economic conditions improved moderately in the Sixth District
On balance, many firms expressed continued hesitancy caused by concerns about healthcare reform in terms of their overall hiring plans
Overall, applications for mortgage loans were down as refinancing activity slowed
Manufacturers also noted that commodity prices were relatively flat and employment modestly increased
Reports indicated that unsold inventory levels were flat to slightly down
Automotive dealers continued to cite solid vehicle sales
The First District economy continues to expand modestly, according to business contacts
Many other contacts report relatively strong sales
One source notes, "[the market] lost a little steam in Q3 and continued at a slower pace in Q4

Credit conditions loosened slightly over the reporting period
The pace of hiring picked up, as did expectations of future hiring
Construction and real estate activity increased modestly in late November and December
Growth in consumer spending picked up to a moderate pace in late November and December, with holiday sales modestly exceeding expectations
Payrolls held steady
The rate of decline in coal production is slowing
Consumer credit demand was described as steady or down slightly
Stel shipments during the fourth quarter were generally characterized as stable or slowly increasing

Prices increased mildly at several responding firms, and employment held steady or rose modestly
Reports of upward wage pressure increased

Retailers reported a slight increase in prices and expected modest price growth in the coming months

Contacts in several Districts reported concerns about health care cost inflation
Most District reports indicated that cost pressures remained stable or increased only slightly

Residential real estate loans declined in the New York, Cleveland, Atlanta, Chicago, and Kansas City Districts, mostly due to slowdowns in refinancing activity rather than in new purchase loan applications; in fact, the latter have slightly increased in some Districts
Contacts in several Districts reported concerns about health care cost inflation
Residential construction saw slight to moderate increases in most Districts; by contrast, Dallas cited a slight decline, New York reported no change, and Cleveland cited strong growth
The Richmond District reported flat to slower bookings in recent weeks, except for resorts specializing in winter activities

Most bankers indicate that average deposit rates are unchanged
Business contacts also express increasingly widespread optimism about the near-term outlook

Despite a slower pace of growth in some sectors, contacts overall maintained an outlook for moderate growth--similar to the last Beige Book
